canvas:CanvasModel.name: Enterprise Architecture Repository
canvas:CanvasModel.documentation:
St. Jude Hosptial Enterprise Architecture has adpated the TOGAF (The Open Group Architecture Framework) Content Framework in which is a crucial part of the TOGAF standard, working in tandem with the Architecture Development Method (ADM). The ADM provides the process for developing an enterprise architecture, while the Content Framework defines what the architecture should look like, ensuring consistency and completeness of the work products generated during the ADM process.
Here's a breakdown of the TOGAF Content Framework and the ADM phases:
1. TOGAF Content Framework:
Purpose: Provides a structured metamodel for architectural artifacts and a conceptual outline of architecture deliverables.
Key Elements:
• Deliverables: Contractually specified work products formally reviewed and approved by stakeholders. • Artifacts: Architectural work products describing an aspect of the architecture, such as diagrams, matrices, and catalogs. • Building Blocks: Potentially reusable components of business, IT, or architectural capability.
2. TOGAF Architecture Development Method (ADM) Phases:
The ADM is an iterative, cyclical approach for developing an enterprise architecture.

children.notes: Models are intended to capture the surrounding context of formal architecture models, including general Architecture Principles, strategic context that forms input for architecture modeling, and requirements generated from the architecture The relevant aspects of the business context that have given rise to the Request for Architecture work are typically investigated, refined, validated, and recorded in the Preliminary and Architecture Vision phases.

Architecture Requirements (Central Function)
Purpose: Ensure requirements are identified, stored, and addressed continuously.
• Operates Across All Phases
Outputs: Requirements Repository, Traceability Matrix.

Preliminary Phase: Preparation and Initiation
Purpose: Define how architecture will be conducted in the enterprise.
Key Activities:
• Define architecture principles. • Establish architecture capability. • Identify stakeholders and governance framework.
Outputs: Architecture Principles, Governance Framework, Architecture Repository structure.

Phase A: Architecture Vision
Purpose: Set the high-level vision for the architecture project.
Key Activities:
• Define scope, constraints, and expectations. • Identify stakeholders and their concerns. • Develop Business Scenario. • Define value proposition.
Outputs: Architecture Vision, Statement of Architecture Work, Stakeholder Map, Business Scenarios.

Architecture Definition (Core Concept)
The Architecture Definition provides a comprehensive description of the enterprise architecture and includes baseline, target, and transition states.
Key Components:
Component s and Descriptions:
Architecture Vision: High-level description of the future state and value proposition
Baseline Architecture: Description of the current state across business, data, application, and technology
Target Architecture: Future state architecture that addresses strategic goals
Transition Architecture: Interim states that guide transformation in phases
Architecture Roadmap: Timeline and work packages leading to the target state
Architecture Definition Document (ADD): The full specification capturing all views, models, and narratives ______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
Architecture Definition Document (ADD) Includes:
1. Executive Summary 2. Scope & Objectives 3. Principles, Goals, and Drivers 4. Baseline & Target Architectures (across domains) 5. Architecture Models (views and diagrams) 6. Gap Analysis 7. Solutions & Building Blocks 8. Dependencies and Constraints 9. Transition Plan

The Motivation extension in TOGAF answers the “why” behind the architecture. It captures intent, rationale, and direction for enterprise architecture decisions. Purpose:
To ensure that architectural decisions are traceable back to business goals, drivers, and stakeholder concerns.
Key Elements of the Motivation Extension:
Stakeholder : Any person or group with an interest in the system (e.g., CEO, CIO, Compliance Officer).
Concern: A high-level interest or worry (e.g., security, performance, cost reduction).
Driver: Internal or external forces prompting change (e.g., new regulation, market disruption).
Goal : High-level statement of intent (e.g., "Improve customer satisfaction").
Objective: A measurable outcome aligned with a goal (e.g., "Reduce customer complaints by 25%").
Requirement: A formal statement that must be met (e.g., "System must support GDPR").
Assessment: Evaluation of current performance, risks, or opportunities (e.g., SWOT analysis).
Example of a Motivation Chain:
Driver → Goal → Objective → Requirement
Example:
• Driver: Government enacts new data privacy law • Goal: Ensure legal compliance • Objective: Achieve GDPR readiness within 6 months • Requirement: Implement data encryption and consent tracking
How It Fits into the TOGAF Framework:
• The Motivation section feeds into the Architecture Vision (Phase A). • It provides the strategic justification for the entire architecture effort. • It's modeled using Motivation Models (e.g., goal trees, driver maps).

Business Architecture
Purpose: Develop the Business Architecture that supports the agreed Architecture Vision.
Key Activities:
• Define current (baseline) and target Business Architecture. • Perform gap analysis. • Validate architecture against business goals.
Outputs: Business Architecture Model, Gap Analysis Report, Business Architecture Components.

Information Systems Architecture
Divided into two sub-parts:
1. Data Architecture 2. Application Architecture
Data Architecture:
• Purpose: Define data entities and relationships. • Outputs: Data models (logical & physical), data management policies.
Application Architecture:
• Purpose: Define individual applications, their interactions, and relationships. • Outputs: Application Communication Diagrams, Interface Catalogs, Application Portfolio.

Data Architecture:
• Purpose: Define data entities and relationships. • Outputs: Data models (logical & physical), data management policies.

Application Architecture:
• Purpose: Define individual applications, their interactions, and relationships. • Outputs: Application Communication Diagrams, Interface Catalogs, Application Portfolio.

Technology Architecture
Purpose: Define the baseline and target technology platforms (infrastructure).
Key Activities:
• Create platform models. • Align tech choices with business/applications.
Outputs: Technology Architecture Models, Tech Standards, Infrastructure Diagrams.
Key Components:
• Technology platform • Network infrastructure • Server infrastructure • Storage infrastructure • Cloud services • Security infrastructure

Architecture Realization is the part of TOGAF that bridges the gap between architecture design (what you want to achieve) and solution implementation (how you make it real).
It involves identifying and organizing the solutions, work packages, projects, and transformation activities necessary to realize the architecture vision.
Key Elements of Architecture Realization:
Work Package: A set of architecture work or projects needed to implement part of the architecture. Think of it as a manageable unit of change.
Project : A formal initiative that delivers one or more work packages.
Solution Building Block (SBB): Implementable components (e.g., a CRM system, cloud service) that support the architecture.
Implementation State: A stage that describes where a solution is in its lifecycle (e.g., planned, deployed, retired).
Architecture Contract: An agreement between development and architecture teams ensuring compliance and delivery of agreed capabilities.
Transition Architecture: Intermediate architecture states that allow gradual movement toward the Target Architecture.
Architecture Roadmap: Timeline that defines when and how each solution or work package will be delivered.
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
How Architecture Realization Fits into TOGAF ADM
Phase Activity Related to Realization Phase E: Opportunities & Solutions Identify major work packages and transformation initiatives. Phase F: Migration Planning Plan the timeline and order of implementation. Phase G: Implementation Governance Oversee the actual realization and check alignment with architecture.
Example of Architecture Realization in Practice:
Target Architecture Goal: Implement a cloud-based customer portal
SBBs : AWS EC2, S3, Lambda, Authentication microservice
Work Package 1: Develop secure user login system
Work Package 2: Migrate customer data to cloud
Project: “Customer Portal Initiative” project containing both packages
Roadmap: Q1: Package 1 → Q2: Package 2 → Q3: Full deployment
Architecture Contract Agreed rules on cloud security, performance, and data privacy

Opportunities and Solutions:
Purpose: Identify major work packages and transition architectures.
Key Activities:
• Prioritize projects and solutions. • Define transition roadmap. • Identify reuse opportunities.
Outputs: Solutions Architecture, Project Portfolio, Transition Architectures. _______________________________________________________________________________________________________
Migration Planning:
Purpose: Develop detailed Implementation and Migration Plan.
Key Activities:
• Create migration strategy and timelines. • Align with business value. • Perform risk assessments.
Outputs: Migration Plan, Implementation Roadmap, Benefits Realization Plan.

Implementation Governance
Purpose: Ensure implementation projects conform to the architecture.
Key Activities:
• Conduct Architecture Contract management. • Monitor implementation progress. • Resolve architecture deviations.
Outputs: Compliance Assessments, Change Requests, Architecture Contract.

As a cross-cutting concern, the Security Architecture impacts and informs the Business, Data, Application, and Technology Architectures. The Security Architecture may often be organized outside of the architecture scope, yet parts of it need to be developed in an integrated fashion with the architecture
